Research Paper Metal-organic frameworks supported iron catalysts for isoprene polymerization Qingtao Niu Writing – original draft Investigation Formal analysis a Maifen Yang Resources Investigation a Xingan Wang Resources Investigation a Aihua He Methodology b Manman Jin Project administration a ⁎ a School of Chemistry, Chemical Engineering and Materials, Jining University, Qufu, Shandong, 273155, China School of Chemistry, Chemical Engineering and Materials Jining University Qufu Shandong 273155 China aSchool of Chemistry, Chemical Engineering and Materials, Jining University, Qufu, Shandong, 273155, China b Shandong Provincial Key Laboratory of Olefin Catalysis and Polymerization, Key Laboratory of Rubber-Plastics (Ministry of Education), School of Polymer Science and Engineering, Qingdao University of Science and Technology, Qingdao, Shandong, 266042, China Shandong Provincial Key Laboratory of Olefin Catalysis and Polymerization, Key Laboratory of Rubber-Plastics (Ministry of Education), School of Polymer Science and Engineering Qingdao University of Science and Technology Qingdao Shandong 266042 China bShandong Provincial Key Laboratory of Olefin Catalysis and Polymerization, Key Laboratory of Rubber-Plastics (Ministry of Education), School of Polymer Science and Engineering, Qingdao University of Science and Technology, Qingdao, Shandong, 266042, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Immobilization of active site on solid support plays great roles in improving catalyst performance. In this study, a series of solid supported iron precatalysts via the immobilization of iron halides (FeXn, X = Cl, Br or I, n = 2 or 3) on the metal-organic frameworks of UiO type bearing bipyridine moiety (bpy-UiO) were synthesized and used for isoprene polymerization. These bpy-UiO supported iron precatalysts (bpy-UiO-FeXn) were also well characterized by the powder X-ray diffraction, elemental analysis and N2 adsorption measurement. Upon activation with trialkylaluminums (AlEt3, Al(i-Bu)3 and AlOct3), bpy-UiO-FeXn exhibited excellent catalytic activity for isoprene polymerization. Interestingly, the iron(III) precatalysts had higher activity than the iron(II) precatalysts, and the highest activity was 1726.4 Kg⋅P/(mol⋅Fe⋅h) for bpy-UiO-FeBr3 with AlEt3. Moreover, the activity gradually increased as the polymerization temperature increased from 0 °C to 50 °C, reflecting the fact that the MOFs supported iron catalysts had excellent thermal stability. Notably, the obtained polyisoprene had the ultrahigh molecular weight (M w = 1.20×106–3.13×106 Daltons), and predominantly consisted of 38.5–54.4 mol % cis-1,4 configuration and 45.6–61.5 mol % 3,4-configuration. This work offers an opportunity to design the high active and stable iron catalyst for conjugated diene polymerization based on the solid support. Graphical abstract Immobilization of center metal on the solid support is an effective strategy to improve catalytic performance, owing to the high dispersion and isolation of active site. A series of MOFs supported iron precatalysts (bpy-UiO-FeXn) were synthesized and used for isoprene polymerization. Upon activation with trialkylaluminums (AlEt3, Al(i-Bu)3 and AlOct3), bpy-UiO-FeXn exhibited excellent catalytic activity for isoprene polymerization. Interestingly, the iron(III) precatalysts had higher activity than the iron(II) precatalysts, and the highest activity was obtained by bpy-UiO-FeBr3 with AlEt3 (1726.4 Kg⋅P/(mol⋅Fe⋅h)). Moreover, the activity gradually increased as the polymerization temperature increased from 0 °C to 50 °C, reflecting the fact that the MOFs supported iron catalysts had excellent thermal stability. Notably, the obtained polyisoprene had the ultrahigh molecular weight (M w = 1.20 × 106–3.13 × 106 Daltons), and predominantly consisted of 38.5–54.4 mol % cis-1,4 configuration and 45.6–61.5 mol % 3,4-configuration. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Metal-organic frameworks Supported iron catalyst Isoprene Polymerization Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction During the past few decades, well-defined single-site iron-based catalysts have attracted a great deal of interest in 1,3-dienes polymerization owing to their features including abundant availability, cost-effectiveness, environmental friendliness, and low toxicity [1–5]. These characters have made them significant to polymerize various kinds of conjugated dienes (e.g., isoprene, butadiene, 3-methyl-1,3-pentadiene) [6–9], giving polymers with different stereoconfigurations, such as trans-1,4, cis-1,4, 3,4- and 1,2-, which significantly define the material physical properties and commercial applications [10–12]. For instance, trans-1,4 polyisoprenes are the crystalline thermoplastic polymers with high toughness and tensile strength at room temperature, and frequently used as the golf ball covers, shape memory materials and medicinal materials [13,14]. Whereas cis-1,4 polyisoprenes are highly elastic and flexible elastomers with low crystallinity, and generally applied in tires, tubes, adhesives, and other industries [15–17]. In addition, 3,4-polyisoprenes with side chains are widely used in the production of high performance tires bearing distinctive low-rolling resistance and wet-skid resistance [18–20]. However, as one of the important late transition metal catalysts, traditional iron-based catalyst typically suffers from rapid deactivation under reaction conditions, low molecular weight of polymer and low productivity, limiting its commercial application. Therefore, great and growing efforts have been made to develop more productive and stable iron-based catalysts based on the development of various bidentate ligands (e.g., bipyridine [6,7,9,12,21,22], iminopyridine [23–26], aminopyridine [27,28]) and tridentate ligands [29–32]. An effective strategy to overcome the shortcoming of homogeneous iron catalysts involves the immobilization of center metal on the solid support, achieving supported iron catalysts with the high dispersion and isolation of active site [33–39]. Semikolenova and Herrmann et al. used silica or alumina as support to prepare the supported catalysts based on 2,6-bis(imino)pyridyl comples of Fe (II) for ethylene polymerization with high and temperature-stable activity [33,34]. Sivaram et al. reported the bis(imino)pyridine iron (II) catalysts supported on clay for the production of polyethylene nanocomposites [36]. Mao et al. developed the spherical supported iron catalysts through the immobilization of bis(imino)pyridyl iron(II) on MgCl2 supports [37,38]. Recently, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), constructed from inorganic nodes and organic linkers, have attracted considerable attention as the emerging porous crystalline molecular materials for developing the well-defined single-site supported catalysts [40–43]. There have also been studies concerning the application of MOFs (e.g., MFU-4I, MIL-103, MIL-100/101) for diene polymerization catalysts [44–48], which mainly involve the effects of MOFs properties including porosity, crystallite size, active site, inorganic nodes and pores on isoprene and butadiene polymerization activity, giving stereoselective polydiene materials. Among the MOFs materials used as catalyst supports, UiO-type MOFs bearing bipyridine moieties in organic linkers (bpy-UiO) possess the exceptional thermal stability and the outstanding preference [49,50]. Lin and co-workers synthesized a series of bpy-UiO supported catalysts based on postsynthetic metalation of MOFs with the iridium, palladium and cobalt complexes for organic transformation reactions [51–53]. Cohen et al. also produced the robust and catalytic bpy-UiO with PdCl2 for Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling reaction [54]. Long et al. further utilized the single-crystal-to single-crystal metalation of bpy-UiO with gas- and solution-phase metal to prepare the structurally well-defined catalysts for arene C-H borylation [55]. However, few details are reported on supported iron catalysts for isoprene polymerization. Inspired by the reported bpy-UiO as the catalyst supports, here we report the synthesis of a series of supported single-site iron-based catalysts utilizing the postsynthetic metalation of bpy-UiO bearing 2,2′-bipyridine moiety with various iron halides (FeCl3, FeBr3, FeCl2, FeI2) for the isoprene polymerization. Upon activation with alkylaluminium (AlR3) cocatalysts, all the iron catalysts exhibited high catalytic activity, and gave polymers with ultrahigh molecular weight and predominant cis-1,4 and 3,4-configurations. To our knowledge, this is the first report of solid iron catalyst supported by MOFs for isoprene polymerization. A detailed polymerization investigation on the effect of polymerization parameters such as AlR3 type, AlR3 concentration and temperature on polymerization behaviors was performed. This work highlights the great potential of designing high active and stable iron-based catalysts for conjugated diene polymerization. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials Zirconium (IV) chloride (ZrCl4, 98 %), 2,2′-bipyridine-5,5′-dicarboxylic acid (98 %), iron (II) chloride (FeCl2, 99.5 %), iron (II) iodide (FeI2, ≥98 %), N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF, 99.5 %) and dichloromethane (CH2Cl2, 99 %) were purchased from Shanghai Macklin Biochenical Co., Ltd and used as received. Iron chloride (FeCl3, ≥99.9 %), iron (III) bromide (FeBr3, 98 %), trifluoroacetic acid (TFA, 99 %), triethylaluminum (AlEt3, 1.0 M in n-hexane), triisobutylaluminum (Al(i-Bu)3, 25 wt % in toluene) and trioctylaluminum (AlOct3, 25 wt % in hexanes) were commercial products and used without further purification. Isoprene (>99 %, purchased from Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd) was first purified through a chromatography column with the anhydrous potassium carbon, alkaline alumina and chromatographic silica gel, then dried over CaH2 and finally distilled prior to use. Acetonitrile (CH3CN, 99 %) and methanol (CH3OH, 99.5 %) were dried over the CaH2 and the activated 4A molecular sieves for 24 h. Xylene was first dried over the activated 4A molecular sieves and then refluxed over Na/benzophenone prior to use. 2.2 Synthesis of MOFs support The bpy-UiO support was synthesized as described in the literatures [51–53]. Briefly, 200 mL DMF, 400 mg 2,2′-bipyridine-5,5′-dicarboxylic acid, 414 mg ZrCl4 was sequentially introduced into a hydrothermal reactor. After being dissolved by the ultrasound and magnetic stirring at room temperature, the mixture with 0.80 mL TFA was heated at 100 °C for 5 days. The resulting solid was centrifuged, thrice immersed in CH2Cl2 during three day, and dried at 45 °C under vacuum for 24 h. 2.3 Preparation of MOFs supported iron precatalysts Under the N2 atmosphere, the preparation of bpy-UiO supported iron precatalysts (bpy-UiO-Fe) was performed as followed: (1) bpy-UiO-FeCl3: 15 mL CH3CN, 2.35 g bpy-UiO and the solution of FeCl3 (536.8 mg) in 9.3 mL CH3CN were sequentially added into a flask with a magnetic stirrer. The mixture was stirred at room temperature for 38 h. After being centrifuged and washed three times by 200 mL CH3CN, the precatalyst was dried at 45 °C under vacuum. (2) bpy-UiO-FeBr3: 15 mL CH3CN, 2.35 g bpy-UiO and the solution of FeBr3 (997.0 mg) in 9.2 mL CH3CN were sequentially added into a flask with a magnetic stirrer. The mixture was stirred at room temperature for 38 h. After being centrifuged and washed three times by 200 mL CH3CN, the precatalyst was dried at 45 °C under vacuum. (3) bpy-UiO-FeCl2: 15 mL CH3CN, 2.35 g bpy-UiO and the solution of FeCl2 (421.0 mg) in 8.2 mL CH3OH were sequentially added into a flask with a magnetic stirrer. The mixture was stirred for 38 h at room temperature. After being centrifuged and washed three times by 200 mL CH3CN, the precatalyst was dried under vacuum at 45 °C. (4) bpy-UiO-FeI2: 15 mL CH3CN, 2.25 g bpy-UiO and the solution of FeI2 (1.0 g) in 6.9 mL CH3OH were sequentially added into a flask with a magnetic stirrer. The mixture was stirred for 38 h at room temperature. After being centrifuged and washed three times by 200 mL CH3CN, the precatalyst was dried under vacuum at 45 °C. 2.4 Isoprene polymerization Isoprene polymerizations were carried out in 100 round-bottom flasks with magnetic stirrers. Calculated amount of isoprene (30 wt % in xylene), AlR3 (Al/Fe = 50 or 100 mol/mol) and bpy-UiO-Fe precatalyst (Ip/Fe = 10,000 mol/mol) were successively added into the purged flasks. Polymerizations were performed at desired temperature for 15 min, and terminated by the alcohol with small amounts of concentrated HCl. The resulting product was first washed times with excess alcohol, and then dried at 45 °C under vacuum for 24 h. The yield was determined by gravimetry in which the catalyst weight was deducted from product weight. 2.5 Characterization The Fe content of precatalyst was characterized by the inductively coupled argon plasma (ICP) analysis with an optical emission spectroscopy spectrometer (OPTIMA 2100 DV). The characterization of powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) was performed using a vertical goniometer (Rint 2000) with Cu Kα radiation. N2 adsorption measurement was performed using an ASAP 2020 Micromeritics sorptometer at 77K. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra of polymers were characterized with a spectrometer (HGCS20170343J) using KBr pellet technique. The 1H NMR and 13C NMR spectra of polymers were characterized by a Bruker spectrometer (100 MHz) with the chloroform-d (CDCl3) using tetramethylsilane (TMS) as standard. The microstructure of polyisoprene was analyzed according to the FT-IR and 13C NMR spectra, and the molar content was calculated based on the 1H NMR spectra.The molecular weight (M w) and molecular weight distribution (M w/M n) of polymer was measured by a HLC-8320GPC gel permeation chromatography with THF at 45 °C and calibrated by polystyrene standards. 3 Result and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and characterization of support and precatalyst The bpy-UiO support bearing bipyridine moiety was prepared by the solvothermal reaction of 2,2′-bipyridine-5,5′-dicarboxylic acid and ZrCl4 in DMF with a small amount of TFA, and the bpy-UiO supported iron precatalysts were subsequently synthesized via the postsynthetic metalation of bpy-UiO supports with 3 equiv. of FeXn (FeCl3, FeBr3, FeCl2 or FeI2) in the presence of CH3CN / CH3CN and methanol (Scheme 1 ). The support and precatalyst were further characterized by PXRD, ICP and N2 adsorption measurement, respectively. The PXRD pattern (Fig. 1(a) ) of the synthesized bpy-UiO was similar to that of the reported crystalline material bearing the expected structure [51], and the crystallinity of MOFs support was well preserved in all bpy-UiO-Fe precatalysts because of their similar PXRD patterns to that of the MOFs support. ICP analysis showed that the Fe contents of precatalysts were 2.69 wt %, 1.96 wt %, 2.75 wt % and 1.51 wt % for bpy-UiO-FeCl3, bpy-UiO-FeBr3, bpy-UiO-FeCl2 and bpy-UiO-FeI2 (Table 1 ), revealing the Fe loading of 18.6 mol %, 13.9 mol %, 18.7 mol % and 10.5 mol % with respect to the metalated bridging ligands, respectively. N2 adsorption measurements (Fig. 1(b–f) and Table 1) gave the BET surface areas and pore volumes of 443.2 m2/g and 0.34 cm3/g, 398.9 m2/g and 0.32 cm3/g, 471.4 m2/g and 0.32 cm3/g, 492.4 m2/g and 0.40 cm3/g for bpy-UiO-FeCl3, bpy-UiO-FeBr3, bpy-UiO-FeCl2, bpy-UiO-FeI2, which were smaller than that of the MOFs support (563.7 m2/g and 0.44 cm3/g). The decrease in surface areas and pore volumes of the supported precatalysts was coincident with the covalent attachment of iron halides via the organic linkers of MOFs. 3.2 Isoprene polymerization performance To investigate the catalytic performances, a series of isoprene polymerizations using the MOFs supported iron precatalysts, in combination with AlEt3, Al(i-Bu)3 and AlOct3, were carried out. The influences of polymerization conditions including AlR3 type, Al/Fe ratio and temperature on polymerization behaviors, such as catalytic activity, molecular weight of polymer, regio- and stereoselectivity, were studied in detail. The polymerization dates obtained were summarized in Table 2 . Upon activation with AlR3 cocatalysts, all the bpy-UiO-Fe precatalysts with different halogens exhibited very high catalytic activities for isoprene polymerizations. Among them, the iron(III) precatalysts possessed the higher catalytic activities. For example, the activities of bpy-UiO-FeCl3 and bpy-UiO-FeBr3 at Al/Fe = 50 mol/mol and 50 °C were 1328.5 Kg⋅P/(mol⋅Fe⋅h) and 1726.4 Kg⋅P/(mol⋅Fe⋅h) (Table 2, Run 4 and 10). The high activity of the supported iron catalysts was likely attributed to the high dispersion and isolation of active site on MOFs support, which prevented the intermolecular deactivation pathways [33–35]. The lower catalytic activity of 677.1 Kg⋅P/(mol⋅Fe⋅h) (Table 2, Run 16) was clearly observed in the bpy-UiO-FeCl2 at the same polymerization condition. In addition, when the halogen atom of byp-UiO-FeCl2 was changed into I atom (bpy-UiO-FeI2), the catalytic activity further reduced to 600.4 Kg⋅P/(mol⋅Fe⋅h) (Table 2, Run 22). This decreasing trend indicated that the local environment of Fe center in terms of the type and number of pendant halogen atom significantly determined the catalyst performance. Similar influences had also been described in the literatures on the homogeneous iron-based catalysts [30,56,57]. In generally, the acidic and basic character of the metal center and ligand significantly determined the catalytic activity [58,59]. The higher Lewis acidic character of Fe center and the stronger conjugated based feature of halogen ligand facilitated the faster coordination of monomer and abstraction of alkylaluminum cocatalyst [30,56,57]. The microstructures of the obtained polyisoprenes were analyzed by the FT-IR, 1H NMR (Fig. S1-Fig. S4) and 13C NMR. The representative FT-IR, 1H NMR and 13C NMR spectra of the polymers were shown in Fig. 2 . In FT-IR spectra (Fig. 2(a)), the absorption bands at 1375 cm−1 and 890 cm−1 represented the cis-1,4 units and 3,4-units. The typical absorption bands of trans-1,4 units at 1385 cm−1 and 1,2-units at 910 cm−1 were not been observed, indicating that no trans-1,4 units and 1,2-units were present along the polyisoprene chains [59,60]. In 13C NMR spectra (Fig. 2(c)), the peaks at different chemical shits corresponding to the various olefinic carbons of cis-1,4 and 3,4-units were assigned as the reported papers [27,61,62]. The characteristic peaks of trans-1,4 units at 39.8 ppm and 16.0 ppm were not detectable [63,64], further confirming the indication of FT-IR spectra of polymers. The amounts of cis-1,4 and 3,4-units were determined based on the 1H NMR spectra [59,65]. All the precatalysts afforded polyisoprenes with slightly different microstructure contents of cis-1,4 units (38.5 mol %-54.4 mol %) and 3,4-units (45.6 mol %-61.5 mol %) (Table 2 and Fig. 3(a) ). For instance, the bpy-UiO-FeCl3 gave polyisoprene with 41.6 mol % cis-1,4 units and 58.4 mol % 3,4-units (Table 2, Run 1), while the bpy-UiO-FeI2 provided polymer bearing 42.4 mol % cis-1,4 units and 57.6 mol % 3,4-units (Table 2, Run 19) at the same polymerization condition. These results indicated that the coordinated halides of iron active sites had no notable effect on the stereoselectivity of MOFs supported iron catalyst, which was different from the influence of halides on Ziegler-Natta type catalysts in which the cis-1,4 stereoselectivity gradually decreased while the trans-1,4 stereoselectivity increased as the halides changed from Cl to Br and I [66–68]. In addition, the polyisoprenes generated by the MOFs supported iron catalysts had the ultrahigh molecular weight in the range of 1.20×106 to 3.05×106 Daltons (Table 2), which was impressive in comparison to the typical iron complexes with low molecular weight in the range of 0.02×106–1.1×106 [21,23,26–29]. The relatively narrow (2.35–3.57) and unimodal molecular weight distribution (Fig. 3(b)) suggested that the single site nature of the active species. Polymerization temperature is great important for the industrial production of polymers. Isoprene polymerizations with varied reaction temperatures in the range of 5 °C to 50 °C were performed to study the dependence of polymerization behaviors on temperature (Fig. 4 ). With the increasing polymerization temperature from 5 °C to 50 °C, the catalytic activity gradually increased from 358.7 Kg⋅P/(mol⋅Fe⋅h), 552.7 Kg⋅P/(mol⋅Fe⋅h), 140.7 Kg⋅P/(mol⋅Fe⋅h) and 150.2 Kg⋅P/(mol⋅Fe⋅h) to 1328.5 Kg⋅P/(mol⋅Fe⋅h), 1726.4 Kg⋅P/(mol⋅Fe⋅h), 677.1 Kg⋅P/(mol⋅Fe⋅h) and 600.4 Kg⋅P/(mol⋅Fe⋅h) for bpy-UiO-FeCl3, bpy-UiO-FeBr3, bpy-UiO-FeCl2 and bpy-UiO-FeI2, respectively. The results indicated that the active species immobilized on the solid MOFs supports exhibited excellent thermal stability during the polymerization process, which was a remarkable enhancing in catalyst performance in comparison to the reported homogeneous iron catalysts with poor thermostability [11]. For instance, the polyisoprene yield evidently reduced from 99 % (81.6×104 g/(mol⋅h)) at 25 °C to 71 % (58.0×104 g/(mol⋅h)) at 50 °C in the aminopyridine iron catalyst system [27]. The microstructures of the polyisoprenes slightly changed with the increasing polymerization temperature, revealing that temperature had little impact on the stereoselectivity of active sites (Fig. 4(b and c)). The molecular weight of polymers gradually enhanced from 2.69×106 Daltons at 5 °C to 3.13×106 Daltons at 50 °C (Fig. 4(d)), which was in agreement with the influence of polymerization temperature on molecular weight of polymers [69–71]. As one of the important components of catalyst system, alkylaluminum has key roles in olefin coordination polymerization. AlEt3, Al(i-Bu)3 and AlOct3 were used as cocatalysts to activate the MOFs supported iron precatalysts for isoprene polymerizations. It can be seen that AlEt3 had the highest activity, and then with the changing of cocatalysts from AlEt3 to Al(i-Bu)3 and AlOct3, the catalytic activity gradually decreased (Fig. 5(a) ). For example, the activities of AlEt3, Al(i-Bu)3 and AlOct3 for bpy-UiO-FeBr3 were 1406.8 Kg⋅P/(mol⋅Fe⋅h), 312.5 Kg⋅P/(mol⋅Fe⋅h) and 59.9 Kg⋅P/(mol⋅Fe⋅h) (Table 2, Run 7, 11 and 12), respectively. This was attributed to the higher alkylating and reducing ability of AlR3 bearing the small ethyl groups, forming more active species on the solid supports. Similar effect had also been reported in MgCl2 supported Ziegler-Natta catalysts [72–76]. Changing alkylaluminum type showed slight influence on the microstructures of polyisoprenes (Fig. 5(c and e)), but presented obvious effect on the molecular weight of polymers in the order of AlEt3 > Al(i-Bu)3 > AlOct3 (Fig. 5(g)). Al/Fe ratio also had great influence on the behaviors of isoprene polymerization. With the increasing Al/Fe ratio from 50 mol/mol to 100 mol/mol, the catalytic activity gradually increased (Fig. 5(b)), and the molecular weight of polymers reduced from 3.05×106 Daltons to 2.73×106 Daltons (Fig. 5(h)), showing the increasing chain transfer reaction of alkylaluminum [77,78]. Nevertheless, the stereoselectivity of polymers showed little change as the Al/Fe ratios increased (Fig. 5(d and f)). 4 Conclusions In conclusion, solid supported iron precatalysts based on the covalent attachment of iron halide via organic linker of MOFs were prepared and well characterized. Precatalysts had similar crystal structure, lower surface area and lower pore volume comparing with MOFs support. These precatalysts in combination with trialkylaluminums exhibited excellent catalytic activity (up to 1726.4 Kg⋅P/(mol⋅Fe⋅h)), giving polyisoprene with the ultrahigh molecular weight (1.20–3.13×106 Daltons) and the mixed cis-1,4 and 3,4- structure. AlEt3 had the highest polymerization activity and highest molecular weight of polymer comparing with Al(i-Bu)3 and AlOct3. In addition, the increase in AlR3 concentration led to the increasing polymerization activity and the decreasing molecular weight of polymers. The MOFs supported iron catalysts generated thermally stable active species, which could efficiently improve isoprene polymerization at high temperature. coredata.dc:description: Immobilization of active site on solid support plays great roles in improving catalyst performance. In this study, a series of solid supported iron precatalysts via the immobilization of iron halides (FeXn, X = Cl, Br or I, n = 2 or 3) on the metal-organic frameworks of UiO type bearing bipyridine moiety (bpy-UiO) were synthesized and used for isoprene polymerization. These bpy-UiO supported iron precatalysts (bpy-UiO-FeXn) were also well characterized by the powder X-ray diffraction, elemental analysis and N2 adsorption measurement. Upon activation with trialkylaluminums (AlEt3, Al(i-Bu)3 and AlOct3), bpy-UiO-FeXn exhibited excellent catalytic activity for isoprene polymerization. Interestingly, the iron(III) precatalysts had higher activity than the iron(II) precatalysts, and the highest activity was 1726.4 Kg⋅P/(mol⋅Fe⋅h) for bpy-UiO-FeBr3 with AlEt3. Moreover, the activity gradually increased as the polymerization temperature increased from 0 °C to 50 °C, reflecting the fact that the MOFs supported iron catalysts had excellent thermal stability. Notably, the obtained polyisoprene had the ultrahigh molecular weight (M w = 1.20×106–3.13×106 Daltons), and predominantly consisted of 38.5–54.4 mol % cis-1,4 configuration and 45.6–61.5 mol % 3,4-configuration. This work offers an opportunity to design the high active and stable iron catalyst for conjugated diene polymerization based on the solid support.
